entry.title: Pavan Tauh

author.name: by Michelle Patten, Paul Riddle, Pavan Tauh and Ben Wise

entry.summary: Pavan Tauh is a sophomore at UT Dallas studying Biology. He is proficient in website design and research gathering. He became involved in this project from interest in researching factors that lead to the disease spreading through the Native American population so quickly. Outside…
entry.content:
Pavan Tauh is a sophomore at UT Dallas studying Biology. He is proficient in website design and research gathering. He became involved in this project from interest in researching factors that lead to the disease spreading through the Native American population so quickly.  Outside of class, Pavan is an avid photographer who enjoys hiking through nature, going to the beach, and cruising on his skateboard.  

Contact Information: pkt180000@utdallas.edu

author.name: by Michelle Patten, Paul Riddle, Pavan Tauh and Ben Wise

entry.title: Method

author.name: by Michelle Patten, Paul Riddle, Pavan Tauh and Ben Wise

entry.summary: To begin our project, we accumulated data from online scholarly articles and books from our library. We searched for maps, movements of diseases and facts of disease spread. We also emailed tribal leaders for any information and guidance they could provide. Next, we compiled these…
entry.content:
To begin our project, we accumulated data from online scholarly articles and books from our library. We searched for maps, movements of diseases and facts of disease spread. We also emailed tribal leaders for any information and guidance they could provide.

Next, we compiled these datapoints into an Excel sheet and added metadata to help with the graphing process. We noted the date, location, disease, source, and any related information that could either explain or be explained from this event.

At the same time, we built a website first through WordPress, but eventually we changed it to GitHub, using Publii to design it. We looked to other map projects such as Photogrammar and al Turraya to learn what features were possible in Leaflet (our mapping tool), and which ones we wanted to add to our own map.

As we gained new insights, we wrote them down into a PowerPoint and document. We presented what knowledge we gained to our peers. With their help, we created a document with feedback and ways for us to improve and clarify our project.

The map came next, with us adding datapoints to create a basic map in leaflet.

Finally, we compiled our information online. 

These tools were chosen to help us create our project in an efficient and accurate way. Microsoft Word and Google Docs were used to write, with Word being superior offline and Docs being superior for collaboration. Google Sheets allowed each of us to add datapoints gathered to a common place. These datapoints allowed us to build the map in Leaflet, which we chose for its features (gathered in other DH projects) and compatibility. Github and Publii were chosen to build and host the website. A peer recommended these programs to us, and we enjoyed using them.

entry.title: Map

author.name: by Michelle Patten, Paul Riddle, Pavan Tauh and Ben Wise

entry.summary: While our map is currently under contruction, presented above is a snapshot with our datapoints for Syphilis plotted in grey. As we progress we hope to add different map overlays and connect the points of common diseases to create a visual web.
entry.content: While our map is currently under contruction, presented above is a snapshot with our datapoints for Syphilis plotted in grey. As we progress we hope to add different map overlays and connect the points of common diseases to create a visual web.

entry.summary: Ben Wise is a sophomore studying visual and performing arts. Outside of class, he is the director of the Comet Opera Chorus, a member of the Dallas Symphony Chorus, and a defensive specialist on the UT Dallas men’s volleyball team.

entry.summary: Michelle is a sophomore from Sammamish, WA, now living in Richardson, TX studying pure mathematics at UT Dallas. She serves as the programming head of this project, in addition to her research in mathematics. Aside from research, she spends most of her time climbing…
entry.content:
Michelle is a sophomore from Sammamish, WA, now living in Richardson, TX studying pure mathematics at UT Dallas. She serves as the programming head of this project, in addition to her research in mathematics. Aside from research, she spends most of her time climbing or writing for the university's opinion magazine.

Contact Info: map171630@utdallas.edu

entry.title: Sources

author.name: by Michelle Patten, Paul Riddle, Pavan Tauh and Ben Wise

entry.summary: Videos: CGP Grey Video: “Americapox: The Missing Plaque” https://youtu.be/JEYh5WACqEk eHistory.org Video:“The Invasion of America” https://youtu.be/pJxrTzfG2bo Books: Crosby, Alfred W. The Columbian Exchange: Biological and Cultural Consequences of 1492. New York: Praeger, 2003. Seed, Patricia. Ceremonies of Possession: Europe’s Conquest of the New World, 1492– 1640.
entry.content:
Videos:

CGP Grey Video:

“Americapox: The Missing Plaque” https://youtu.be/JEYh5WACqEk

eHistory.org Video:“The Invasion of America” https://youtu.be/pJxrTzfG2bo



Books:

Cook, Noble David. Born to Die: Disease and New World Conquest, 1492–1650. New               York: Cambridge University Press, 1998.

Crosby, Alfred W. The Columbian Exchange: Biological and Cultural Consequences of               1492. New York: Praeger, 2003.

Seed, Patricia. Ceremonies of Possession: Europe’s Conquest of the New World, 1492–           1640. New York: Cambridge University Press, 1995.

Schwartz, Stuart B. Victors and Vanquished: Spanish and Nahua Views of the                           Conquest of Mexico. New York: Bedford St. Martin’s, 2000.

Articles:

Nunn, Nathan and Qian, Nancy. The Columbian Exchange: A History of Disease, Food,             and Ideas. The Journal of Economic Perspectives. Spring 2010. Vol 24(2), pp.                 163-188. https://web.viu.ca/davies/H131/ColumbianExchange.pdf

Jr, Alfred W Crosby. “The Early History of Syphilis: A Reappraisal.” American                              Anthropologist. 71.2 (1969): 218-227. Web.

Dennie, Charles. 1962. A History of Syphilis. Springfield: Thomas.

Harrison, L.W. 1959. “The Origin of Syphilis.” British Journal of Venereal Diseases, 35(1): 1-7.

Sherman, Irwin W. 2007. Twelve Diseases That Changed Our World. Washington, DC: ASM Press.

Snodgrass, Mary Ellen. 2003. World Epidemics: A Cultural Chronology of Disease from Prehistory to the Era of SARS. Jefferson, North Carolina: McFarland & Company Inc.

Harper, Kristin N., Paolo S. Ocampo, Bret M. Steiner, Robert W. George, Michael S. Silverman, Shelly Bolotin, Allan Pillay, Nigel J. Saunders, and George J. Armelagos. 2008. “On the Origin of the Treponematoses: A Phylogenetic Approach.” Public Library of Science: Neglected Tropical Diseases, 2(1): 1-13.

Placeholder, Noble David. Born to Die: Disease and New World Conquest, 1492–1650. New York: Cambridge University Press, 1998.

entry.title: Introduction

author.name: by Michelle Patten, Paul Riddle, Pavan Tauh and Ben Wise

entry.summary: While colonizing the Americas, European explorers purposefully spread diseases completely foreign to the land’s natives. The Native Americans had no time to build immune defenses to these often deliberately galvanized pathogens and thus suffered heavily. Info on Columbian ExchangeHistoriography
entry.content:
While colonizing the Americas, European explorers purposefully spread diseases completely foreign to the land’s natives. The Native Americans had no time to build immune defenses to these often deliberately galvanized pathogens and thus suffered heavily.

 

    1. Info on Columbian Exchange
    2. Historiography
